elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Cadmium and zinc coordination polymers containing flexible-arm aromatic ortho-dicarboxylate and bis(pyridyl)piperazine-type ligands have been prepared. {[Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5]⋅4H2O} n  (1, hmph=homophthalate, 4-bpmp=bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) manifests a new 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected 3-D net with a very simple 4466 topology.

<ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">► Cadmium and zinc flexible arm <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-dicarboxylate coordination polymers. ► Bis(pyridyl)piperazine-type neutral ancillary ligands. ► New 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected 3-D net. ► Rare 4,5-connected binodal <ce:bold>tcs</ce:bold> net with (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology. ► Uncommon 3,4-connected binodal layer with V<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> topology.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► Cadmium and zinc flexible arm ortho-dicarboxylate coordination polymers. ► Bis(pyridyl)piperazine-type neutral ancillary ligands. ► New 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected 3-D net. ► Rare 4,5-connected binodal tcs net with (4462)(4466) topology. ► Uncommon 3,4-connected binodal layer with V2O5 topology.

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>

[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,2-phda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpmp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 1,2-phda<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,2-phenylenediacetate) possesses an uncommon 3,4-connected binodal 2-D layer with (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8) (V<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> prototype) topology. [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmph)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) has a decorated (4,4) grid topology with embedded [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] paddlewheel clusters. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reaction of a d 10 configuration divalent metal precursor with flexible-arm aromatic ortho-dicarboxylates and a bis(pyridyl)piperazine-type neutral co-ligand has generated four coordination polymers, some with rare topologies. {[Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5]⋅4H2O} n  (1, hmph=homophthalate, 4-bpmp=bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) manifests a new 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected 3-D net with a very simple 4466 topology, different from the usual sqp 5-connected topology. [Cd2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (2, 4-bpfp=bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine) displays a rare 4,5-connected binodal tcs net with (4462)(4466) topology. [Zn2(1,2-phda)2(4-bpmp)(H2O)2] n  (3, 1,2-phda=1,2-phenylenediacetate) possesses an uncommon 3,4-connected binodal 2-D layer with (426)(42638) (V2O5 prototype) topology. [Zn2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (4) has a decorated (4,4) grid topology with embedded [Zn2(OCO)4] paddlewheel clusters. All materials exhibit ligand-centered fluorescent behavior. Thermal degradation behavior of the 3-D network materials is reported.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The design and structural characterization of coordination polymer solids remain an active research area because of these phases’ growing utility as gas storage materials , molecular absorbents , ion-exchange substrates , catalysts , and in optical devices , along with the underlying appeal of elegant molecular topologies . Divalent zinc and cadmium ions have been commonly used in coordination polymer chemistry for a two fold reason, arising from their <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> closed-shell electronic configuration. The absence of ligand field preferences result in a greater role for the specific electronic, steric, and conformational requirements of the scaffolding ligands in enforcing the final structural topology during self-assembly. Additionally, the lack of any visible light absorption provides the transparency necessary for emissive properties such as fluorescence or second harmonic generation .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and structural characterization of coordination polymer solids remain an active research area because of these phases' growing utility as gas storage materials , molecular absorbents , ion-exchange substrates , catalysts , and in optical devices , along with the underlying appeal of elegant molecular topologies . Divalent zinc and cadmium ions have been commonly used in coordination polymer chemistry for a two fold reason, arising from their d 10 closed-shell electronic configuration. The absence of ligand field preferences result in a greater role for the specific electronic, steric, and conformational requirements of the scaffolding ligands in enforcing the final structural topology during self-assembly. Additionally, the lack of any visible light absorption provides the transparency necessary for emissive properties such as fluorescence or second harmonic generation .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">From a survey of recent literature, it is clear that divalent metal phthalate (pht) coordination polymers containing neutral dipyridyl co-ligands ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>) can manifest a wide range of structural topologies . In these phases, ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) , 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) , bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp) , bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) , and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb)  serve as both dipodal tethers and supramolecular structure-directing agents. By way of example, [Cd(Hpht)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> possesses a self-penetrated 5<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>7 topology 6-connected uninodal 3-D network , constructed from a single 4-connected adamantoid [Cd(Hpht)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> subnet through crossing rigid-rod bpy tethers. {[Cd(pht)(dpa)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> has a uninodal 4-connected network with a unique self-penetrated 7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:bold>yyz</ce:bold> topology built from the interlocking of three chiral (12,3) regular subnets . Longer tethering ligands can afford more complicated multi-nodal topologies, with {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pht)(btb)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·4.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> manifesting complicated 2-D slab motifs with a trinodal (4.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>9)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> topology  and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pht)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpfp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> displaying a rare 4,5-connected binodal net with <ce:bold>tcs</ce:bold> topology . In all of these prior examples, the binding mode of the pht ligands, nitrogen-donor disposition, and inter-ligand hydrogen-bonding play a cooperative structure-directing role.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From a survey of recent literature, it is clear that divalent metal phthalate (pht) coordination polymers containing neutral dipyridyl co-ligands ligands ( ) can manifest a wide range of structural topologies . In these phases, ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) , 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) , bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp) , bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) , and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb)  serve as both dipodal tethers and supramolecular structure-directing agents. By way of example, [Cd(Hpht)2(bpy)] n  possesses a self-penetrated 510647 topology 6-connected uninodal 3-D network , constructed from a single 4-connected adamantoid [Cd(Hpht)2] n  subnet through crossing rigid-rod bpy tethers. {[Cd(pht)(dpa)(H2O)]⋅4H2O} n  has a uninodal 4-connected network with a unique self-penetrated 7482 yyz topology built from the interlocking of three chiral (12,3) regular subnets . Longer tethering ligands can afford more complicated multi-nodal topologies, with {[Cd2(pht)(btb)(H2O)3]⋅4.5(H2O)} n  manifesting complicated 2-D slab motifs with a trinodal (4.72)2(42738)(42739)2 topology  and {[Cd2(pht)2(bpfp)(H2O)2] n  displaying a rare 4,5-connected binodal net with tcs topology . In all of these prior examples, the binding mode of the pht ligands, nitrogen-donor disposition, and inter-ligand hydrogen-bonding play a cooperative structure-directing role.

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Less commonly used in this chemistry than the straight-arm pht ligands are its <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-dicarboxylate analogs homophthalate (hmph) and 1,2-phenylenedicarboxylate (1,2-phda), which possess one and two flexible acetate arms, respectively () . Divalent metal hmph or 1,2-phda coordination polymers can show great differences in topology from their pht analogs, despite the presence of a common dipyridyl tethering ligand. For example, {[Cd(hmph)(dpa)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, hmph<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>homophthalate) possesses interdigitated herringbone grid (6,3) layers , in contrast to the self-penetrated <ce:bold>yyz</ce:bold> net of its pht congener. [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,2-phda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpmp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> has a rare 3,4-connected V<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-type structure with a Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8) , while its pht analog {[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pht)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H4-bpmp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> shows a simple cationic (4,4) rectangular grid topology .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Less commonly used in this chemistry than the straight-arm pht ligands are its ortho-dicarboxylate analogs homophthalate (hmph) and 1,2-phenylenedicarboxylate (1,2-phda), which possess one and two flexible acetate arms, respectively () . Divalent metal hmph or 1,2-phda coordination polymers can show great differences in topology from their pht analogs, despite the presence of a common dipyridyl tethering ligand. For example, {[Cd(hmph)(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  (1, hmph=homophthalate) possesses interdigitated herringbone grid (6,3) layers , in contrast to the self-penetrated yyz net of its pht congener. [Cu2(1,2-phda)2(H2O)2(4-bpmp)] n  has a rare 3,4-connected V2O5-type structure with a Schläfli symbol of (426)(42638) , while its pht analog {[Cu2(pht)2(H4-bpmp)2(H2O)2](NO3)2⋅H2O} n  shows a simple cationic (4,4) rectangular grid topology .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">In this study we have aimed to investigate the topological effects of using the longer acetate arm ligands hmph and 1,2-phda in zinc and cadmium coordination polymers featuring long-spanning dipyridyl ligands 4-bpmp and 4-bpfp, drawing comparisons and contrasts with previously reported pht-containing derivatives. The crystal structures and luminescent properties of four new coordination polymers are discussed herein: {[Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmph)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,2-phda)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpmp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmph)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), with the first three displaying new or rare topological features.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this study we have aimed to investigate the topological effects of using the longer acetate arm ligands hmph and 1,2-phda in zinc and cadmium coordination polymers featuring long-spanning dipyridyl ligands 4-bpmp and 4-bpfp, drawing comparisons and contrasts with previously reported pht-containing derivatives. The crystal structures and luminescent properties of four new coordination polymers are discussed herein: {[Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5]⋅4H2O} n  (1), [Cd2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (2), [Zn2(1,2-phda)2(4-bpmp)(H2O)2] n  (3), and [Zn2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (4), with the first three displaying new or rare topological features.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Cadmium and zinc salts were obtained from Aldrich. Bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine  and bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine  were prepared via published procedures. Water was deionized above 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum One instrument on powdered samples. Elemental analysis was performed by Micro-Analysis, Inc., Wilmington, Delaware, USA. The luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General considerations

Cadmium and zinc salts were obtained from Aldrich. Bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine  and bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine  were prepared via published procedures. Water was deionized above 3MΩcm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument on powdered samples. Elemental analysis was performed by Micro-Analysis, Inc., Wilmington, Delaware, USA. The luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive.

</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), homophthalic acid (32<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4-bpmp (99<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL deionized water were placed into a 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL screw-cap vial. The vial was sealed and heated in an oil bath at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled slowly to 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The data was integrated via <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps>
. Lorentz and polarization effect and absorption corrections were applied with <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>
. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>
. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Where possible, hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules were found by Fourier difference map and refined with isotropic thermal displacement parameters. Relevant crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are listed in

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single crystals of all materials were subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction at 173K using a Bruker-AXS Apex II CCD instrument. Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data was integrated via saint . Lorentz and polarization effect and absorption corrections were applied with sadabs . The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using shelxtl . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Where possible, hydrogen atoms belonging to water molecules were found by Fourier difference map and refined with isotropic thermal displacement parameters. Relevant crystallographic data for 1-4 are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and spectral characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were prepared hydrothermally by the reaction of a zinc or cadmium salt solution, the requisite <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-dicarboxylic acid, and the appropriate dipyridyl ligand. The infrared spectra of all of the compounds were consistent with their crystal structures. Weak, highly broadened features above ∼3200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> indicate the presence of the bound and/or unligated water molecules. Bands between 3050 and 3150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> represent C–H stretching modes. Medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 to ∼1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> arise from stretching modes of the aromatic rings of the dicarboxylate and bpmp ligands. Asymmetric and symmetric C–O stretching modes of the <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-dicarboxylate ligands are present as broadened, intense bands at 1550 and 1383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 1527 and 1359<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), 1553 and 1396<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and 1601 and 1402/1388<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering mechanisms were observed in the region between 600 and 820<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching modes within the amide functional groups of the 4-bpfp ligands appeared as strong bands at 1638 and 1635<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the spectra of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and spectral characterization

Compounds 1-4 were prepared hydrothermally by the reaction of a zinc or cadmium salt solution, the requisite ortho-dicarboxylic acid, and the appropriate dipyridyl ligand. The infrared spectra of all of the compounds were consistent with their crystal structures. Weak, highly broadened features above ~3200cm-1 in the spectra of 1 and 3 indicate the presence of the bound and/or unligated water molecules. Bands between 3050 and 3150cm-1 represent C-H stretching modes. Medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 to ~1200cm-1 arise from stretching modes of the aromatic rings of the dicarboxylate and bpmp ligands. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the ortho-dicarboxylate ligands are present as broadened, intense bands at 1550 and 1383cm-1 (1), 1527 and 1359cm-1 (2), 1553 and 1396cm-1 (3), and 1601 and 1402/1388cm-1 (4). Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering mechanisms were observed in the region between 600 and 820cm-1. The CO stretching modes within the amide functional groups of the 4-bpfp ligands appeared as strong bands at 1638 and 1635cm-1 in the spectra of 2 and 4, respectively.

The coordination environment around cadmium is a distorted {CdN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} octahedron (), with <ce:italic>bpmp-A</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>bpmp-B</ce:italic>, and <ce:italic>bpmp-C</ce:italic> pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms disposed in a <ce:italic>mer</ce:italic> fashion. The <ce:italic>bpmp-A</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>bpmp-B</ce:italic> nitrogen donors are situated <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> to each other. A chelating carboxylate group from one hmph ligand and an oxygen atom from a monodentate carboxylate group from another hmph ligand are also arranged in a <ce:italic>mer</ce:italic> disposition. elements.clean_text:
Structural description of {[Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5]⋅4H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains a divalent cadmium ion, a hmph ligand, three crystallographically independent halves of 4-bpmp molecules (N1-N2, bpmp-A; N3-N4, bpmp-B; N5-N6, bpmp-C), and four water molecules of crystallization. The coordination environment around cadmium is a distorted {CdN3O3} octahedron (), with bpmp-A, bpmp-B, and bpmp-C pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms disposed in a mer fashion. The bpmp-A and bpmp-B nitrogen donors are situated trans to each other. A chelating carboxylate group from one hmph ligand and an oxygen atom from a monodentate carboxylate group from another hmph ligand are also arranged in a mer disposition. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination environment of 1 are listed in  .

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">[Cd(hmph)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain motifs (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a), with a Cd⋯Cd through-ligand contact distance of 9.428<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, are formed through the chelating/monodentate bridging mode of the hmph ligands. While the short carboxylate arm of the hmph ligand is twisted by only 1.6° relative to the aromatic ring plane, the dihedral angle acetate carboxylate group and the aromatic ring plane is much larger, at 71.7°. The [Cd(hmph)]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic> chain motifs are arranged parallel to the [1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] crystal direction. These are connected into a [Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> 3-D coordination polymer network by all 4-bpmp ligands, which join each [Cd(hmph)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chain to three others. The Cd⋯Cd contact distances through the <ce:italic>bpmp-A</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>bpmp-B</ce:italic>, and <ce:italic>bpmp-C</ce:italic> ligands are 17.277, 17.142 and 17.233<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Alternatively, the network can be construed as being formed by the pillaring of [Cd(4-bpmp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (6,3) brick wall layers (b) by hmph ligands. The long span of the 4-bpmp ligands allows mutual 3-fold interpenetration of [Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Cd(hmph)] n  chain motifs ( a), with a Cd⋯Cd through-ligand contact distance of 9.428Å, are formed through the chelating/monodentate bridging mode of the hmph ligands. While the short carboxylate arm of the hmph ligand is twisted by only 1.6° relative to the aromatic ring plane, the dihedral angle acetate carboxylate group and the aromatic ring plane is much larger, at 71.7°. The [Cd(hmph)] n  chain motifs are arranged parallel to the [101] crystal direction. These are connected into a [Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5] n  3-D coordination polymer network by all 4-bpmp ligands, which join each [Cd(hmph)] n  chain to three others. The Cd⋯Cd contact distances through the bpmp-A, bpmp-B, and bpmp-C ligands are 17.277, 17.142 and 17.233Å, respectively. Alternatively, the network can be construed as being formed by the pillaring of [Cd(4-bpmp)1.5] n  (6,3) brick wall layers (b) by hmph ligands. The long span of the 4-bpmp ligands allows mutual 3-fold interpenetration of [Cd(hmph)(4-bpmp)1.5] n  polymer nets ( a).

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be derived by considering each cadmium atom a trigonal bipyramidal 5-connected node and all hmph and 4-bpmp ligands as simple linkers. elements.clean_text: The topology of 1 can be derived by considering each cadmium atom a trigonal bipyramidal 5-connected node and all hmph and 4-bpmp ligands as simple linkers. As determined by TOPOS software , the resulting 3-fold interpenetrated 5-connected network has a very simple 4466 topology (b), with an extended point symbol of 4.4.4.4.6.63.65.65.65.65 and a td 10 value of 1527. This network can be derived from the 6-connected primitive cubic net (pcu) by removing one of the connections to reduce the idealized space group from Pm3m to Pbcn . To the best of our knowledge this 5-connected network has not yet been reported in the coordination polymer literature. It stands in contrast to the more commonly encountered square pyramidal 5-connected sqp net, which also has a 4466 topology, but with an extended point symbol of 4.4.4.4.6.6.65.65.65.65 and a td 10 of value 1366 . The network of 1 also varies from the nov 5-connected net with 4466 topology, seen only in [Cu2(dicyanamide)4(2,5-dimethylpyrazine)] n  . The extended point symbol for the nov net is 4.4.4.4.6.6.63.65.65.65, and it has a td 10 of value 1366.

<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Solvent-accessible cavities within the interpenetrated framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are filled by octameric water molecule clusters with an intriguing R(4)A(4) aggregation pattern  reminiscent of 1,2,3,4-tetramethylcyclobutane (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). These are anchored to the coordination polymer backbone by hydrogen bonding donation to both piperazinyl nitrogen atoms of the 4-bpmp ligands and hmph carboxylate groups (). Hydrogen bonding O⋯O distances within the water clusters range from 2.757(2) to 2.854(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The water clusters occupy 14.4% of the unit cell volume, according to PLATON .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Structural description of [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmph)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains one divalent cadmium atom, one hmph ligand, and one-half of a 4-bpfp molecule whose piperazinyl ring centroid rests on a crystallographic inversion center. A distorted pentagonal bipyramidal {CdO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>N} environment exists at cadmium (). In the equatorial plane are situated are two oxygen donors from an hmph ligand chelating via its acetate pendant arm, two oxygen donors from a second hmph ligand provided by both short and long pendant arms, and another oxygen atom belonging to an acetate group of a third hmph ligand. The axial positions are filled by a pyridyl nitrogen donor from a bpfp ligand and an oxygen atom of a short carboxylate arm of a fourth hmph ligand. No bpfp formyl oxygen atoms ligate to cadmium. Bond lengths and angles are consistent with the pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment about cadmium ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [Cd2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (2)

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 contains one divalent cadmium atom, one hmph ligand, and one-half of a 4-bpfp molecule whose piperazinyl ring centroid rests on a crystallographic inversion center. A distorted pentagonal bipyramidal {CdO6N} environment exists at cadmium (). In the equatorial plane are situated are two oxygen donors from an hmph ligand chelating via its acetate pendant arm, two oxygen donors from a second hmph ligand provided by both short and long pendant arms, and another oxygen atom belonging to an acetate group of a third hmph ligand. The axial positions are filled by a pyridyl nitrogen donor from a bpfp ligand and an oxygen atom of a short carboxylate arm of a fourth hmph ligand. No bpfp formyl oxygen atoms ligate to cadmium. Bond lengths and angles are consistent with the pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment about cadmium ().

The short carboxylate arms bridge two cadmium atoms in a bis(monodentate) <ce:italic>anti-syn</ce:italic> configuration. The exotetradentate hmph ligands construct [Cd(hmph)]<ce:italic>

The Cd⋯Cd contact distances across the {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} dimers measure 3.991<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The ribbon motifs connect into the 2-D [Cd(hmph)]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic> layer through <ce:italic>anti-syn</ce:italic> bridging modes of the short hmph carboxylate arms, forming {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OCO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} dimers whose Cd⋯Cd contact distances measure 5.059<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. elements.clean_text: The hmph ligands bind to four cadmium atoms, with the acetate arms adopting a μ3-η2, η1, η1 binding mode. The short carboxylate arms bridge two cadmium atoms in a bis(monodentate) anti-syn configuration. The exotetradentate hmph ligands construct [Cd(hmph)] n  polymeric layers ( ) that are situated parallel to the ab crystal planes. Within the layers are ribbon patterns comprising alternating {Cd2O2} and {CdOCO} four-membered circuits. The Cd⋯Cd contact distances across the {Cd2O2} dimers measure 3.991Å. The ribbon motifs connect into the 2-D [Cd(hmph)] n  layer through anti-syn bridging modes of the short hmph carboxylate arms, forming {Cd2(OCO)2} dimers whose Cd⋯Cd contact distances measure 5.059Å. If the hmph ligands are considered 4-connected nodes, the [Cd(hmph)] n  layers can be represented as buckled (4,4) grids.

Although not uncommon in intermetallic phases such as the ThCr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Si<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> prototype , this net has been rarely seen in coordination polymer chemistry , although the phthalate analog of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has a similar topology despite a different exotetradentate carboxylate binding mode .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Adjacent [Cd(hmph)] n  layers are pillared into a non-interpenetrated 3-D [Cd2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  coordination polymer network ( a) by perfectly anti conformation tethering 4-bpfp ligands, which span a Cd⋯Cd contact distance of 16.688Å. The Cd atoms therefore acts as 5-connected nodes, resulting in a 4,5-connected binodal net (b). Analysis with TOPOS reveals a (4462)(4466) tcs topology, where the first term represents the hmph ligand nodes. Although not uncommon in intermetallic phases such as the ThCr2Si2 prototype , this net has been rarely seen in coordination polymer chemistry , although the phthalate analog of 2 has a similar topology despite a different exotetradentate carboxylate binding mode .

Structural description of [Zn2(1,2-phda)2(4-bpmp)(H2O)2] n  (3)

The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains one divalent zinc atom, an aqua ligand, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one-half of a 4-bpmp ligand whose piperazinyl ring centroid rests on a crystallographic inversion center (). The zinc atom possesses a distorted square pyramidal (τ =0.284)  {ZnO4N} coordination environment, in which the basal plane contains trans oxygen donor atoms from two different 1,2-phda ligands, an aqua ligand, and a 4-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor atom. In the apical position is a carboxylate oxygen atom belonging to a third 1,2-phda ligand. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination sphere are listed in  .

Structural description of [Zn2(hmph)2(4-bpfp)] n  (4)

Similar to its cadmium analog 2, the asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one divalent metal atom, one hmph ligand, and one-half of a 4-bpfp molecule. The smaller ionic radius of zinc causes a shift to a five-coordinated nearly ideal square pyramidal {ZnO4N} coordination sphere (τ =0.008), where the basal plane contains carboxylate oxygen atom donors from four different hmph ligands (). Donors from two acetate arms of the hmph ligands are arranged in a trans fashion, as are the oxygen atoms belonging to short hmph carboxylate arms. The apical position is occupied by a 4-bpfp pyridyl nitrogen donor atom. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination sphere are listed in .

<ce:section-title>Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were irradiated with ultraviolet light (excitation wavelengths: <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm; <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm; <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm; <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, 265<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), resulting in moderate fluorescence in all cases. The emission maxima were observed at 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 432<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 435<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and 405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Emission spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>. The more intense fluorescence for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be possibly explained by a reduction in non-radiative vibrational energy loss because of their more structurally rigid 3-D topologies, in contrast to the layered topologies of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The luminescent behavior in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is most plausibly ascribed to intraligand π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> or π–<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> transitions, similar to that seen in other <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal coordination polymers constructed from aromatic ligands .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

Polycrystalline samples of 1-4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light (excitation wavelengths: 1, 375nm; 2, 330nm; 3, 300nm; 4, 265nm), resulting in moderate fluorescence in all cases. The emission maxima were observed at 440nm for 1, 432nm for 2, 435nm for 3, and 405nm for 4. Emission spectra for 1-4 are shown in  . The more intense fluorescence for 1 and 2 can be possibly explained by a reduction in non-radiative vibrational energy loss because of their more structurally rigid 3-D topologies, in contrast to the layered topologies of 3 and 4. The luminescent behavior in 1-4 is most plausibly ascribed to intraligand π-π∗ or π-n transitions, similar to that seen in other d 10 metal coordination polymers constructed from aromatic ligands .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Thermal degradation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis under flowing N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was carried out on <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in order to investigate the stability of their respective 3-D coordination polymer networks. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, water molecule and ligand ejection commenced around 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and continued to ∼425<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (), at which temperature the 45.3% mass remnant is consistent with a combination of CdCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (22.5% calc’d) and uncombusted carbonaceous material. No mass loss was observed for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> until ∼305<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon sudden ligand pyrolysis occurred (). The mass remnant of 36.0% was roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (39.2% calc’d). The greater denticity of the hmph ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (exotetradentate versus exobidentate) could provide an enhanced thermal stability of the 3-D framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal degradation of 1 and 2 

Thermogravimetric analysis under flowing N2 was carried out on 1 and 2 in order to investigate the stability of their respective 3-D coordination polymer networks. For 1, water molecule and ligand ejection commenced around 130°C and continued to ~425°C (), at which temperature the 45.3% mass remnant is consistent with a combination of CdCO3 (22.5% calc'd) and uncombusted carbonaceous material. No mass loss was observed for 2 until ~305°C, whereupon sudden ligand pyrolysis occurred (). The mass remnant of 36.0% was roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (39.2% calc'd). The greater denticity of the hmph ligands in 2 (exotetradentate versus exobidentate) could provide an enhanced thermal stability of the 3-D framework.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The long-spanning, hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridyl–piperazine ligands bpmp and bpfp have afforded a topologically diverse series of luminescent zinc and cadmium coordination polymers containing aromatic <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-dicarboxylates with flexible pendant arms. Cadmium homophthalate materials with bpmp (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and bpfp (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) exhibit new 5-connected and rare 4,5-connected three-dimensional topologies, respectively. Although the zinc derivatives in this series show only 2-D coordination polymer connectivity, the 1,2-phda/bpmp phase <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> possesses a very rare 3,4-connected layered topology. The specific carboxylate bridging and binding mode and acetate arm conformation, along with coordination geometry preferences at the divalent metal ion, provide a cooperative structure directing effect. Among the two 3-D phases, greater denticity of the homophthalate ligands appears to promote enhanced thermal stability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The long-spanning, hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridyl-piperazine ligands bpmp and bpfp have afforded a topologically diverse series of luminescent zinc and cadmium coordination polymers containing aromatic ortho-dicarboxylates with flexible pendant arms. Cadmium homophthalate materials with bpmp (1) and bpfp (2) exhibit new 5-connected and rare 4,5-connected three-dimensional topologies, respectively. Although the zinc derivatives in this series show only 2-D coordination polymer connectivity, the 1,2-phda/bpmp phase 3 possesses a very rare 3,4-connected layered topology. The specific carboxylate bridging and binding mode and acetate arm conformation, along with coordination geometry preferences at the divalent metal ion, provide a cooperative structure directing effect. Among the two 3-D phases, greater denticity of the homophthalate ligands appears to promote enhanced thermal stability.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

Polycrystalline samples of 1-4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light (excitation wavelengths: 1, 375nm; 2, 330nm; 3, 300nm; 4, 265nm), resulting in moderate fluorescence in all cases. The emission maxima were observed at 440nm for 1, 432nm for 2, 435nm for 3, and 405nm for 4. Emission spectra for 1-4 are shown in  . The more intense fluorescence for 1 and 2 can be possibly explained by a reduction in non-radiative vibrational energy loss because of their more structurally rigid 3-D topologies, in contrast to the layered topologies of 3 and 4. The luminescent behavior in 1-4 is most plausibly ascribed to intraligand π-π∗ or π-n transitions, similar to that seen in other d 10 metal coordination polymers constructed from aromatic ligands .

Thermal degradation of 1 and 2 

Thermogravimetric analysis under flowing N2 was carried out on 1 and 2 in order to investigate the stability of their respective 3-D coordination polymer networks. For 1, water molecule and ligand ejection commenced around 130°C and continued to ~425°C (), at which temperature the 45.3% mass remnant is consistent with a combination of CdCO3 (22.5% calc'd) and uncombusted carbonaceous material. No mass loss was observed for 2 until ~305°C, whereupon sudden ligand pyrolysis occurred (). The mass remnant of 36.0% was roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (39.2% calc'd). The greater denticity of the hmph ligands in 2 (exotetradentate versus exobidentate) could provide an enhanced thermal stability of the 3-D framework.
